pullRequest.body:
They are superseded by the header linter (#16574).

---

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [5291bffc22](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17556/commits/5291bffc22d612a68392e96929b3eb1ae413282c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`- broadImportsLinter`
`- copyrightHeaderLinter`
`- import_only_check(lines,`
`- isCorrectAuthorsLine`
`- regular_check(lines,`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
@adomani Would you like to review this removal PR? (I am fine with waiting for a few days to land this, out of prudence.)

I suggest an experiment: add a file that breaks the rules and see that the new linter actually catches the errors. But probably people who are more involved in CI and metaprogramming have better ideas.
I just added such a file, the linter works locally. Does that look sufficient to you? (If CI fails, I'll remove it again.)

The internal logic of the headerLinter is tested in `test/HeaderLinter.lean`.  The linter picked up non-complying copyright headers in development and I also think that I did a test similar to the one that Michael just did while developing the linter.

The test here also seems to work: besides the fact that the "new" definition does not have a doc-string, there are also `build` errors coming from the malformed copyright header.

My main reason for not being immediately enthusiastic about removing these "text-based" linters is that the syntax linter will typically lint `Mathlib.Init` and whatever imports that, but the text-based ones also cover the "early" files.

Wasn't the point of `Mathlib.Init` that every file imports it (or is imported in it)?
Checking the copyright headers of all these syntax linters is nice, I agree - but I don't think keeping a separate linter implementation around just for them is an appropriate cost-benefit ratio.

Especially since my not-so-secret medium-term plan is to remove `lint-style.py` entirely; this is one of the blockers towards that.

Right, I simply have not yet accepted that the style-linters will not necessarily by style-compliant, that's all!  I agree that having as much as possible enforced in Lean is a good aim: once CI is happy, I am happy to maintainer merge this PR!

I share your wish that these files should be style-compliant!
For these particular linters, that should not be too hard to enforce by hand, though... in practice, these seem to be violated out of ignorance more than anything else.

@adomani I just wrote #18725, importing the `header` linter in every file that is imported in Mathlib.Init. This should ensure all files are checked for missing copyright (or module doc-string). Does that assugae your concerns on this PR?

This is what was going to happen once the linter had been rewritten as a syntax linter, isn't it?  :wink: 

I'll

maintainer merge

and also ping @bryangingechen, in case there are any last-minute comments!
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by adomani.

LGTM, thanks for the ping!
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11614020806/job/32341199943)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11614020806/job/32341199581)

Looks good to me!

I see that Bryan self-assigned this PR, so I won't maintainer merge, in case he wants to add something, but I am happy with merging it!

Thanks!

Looks good to me!

I see that Bryan self-assigned this PR, so I won't maintainer merge, in case he wants to add something, but I am happy with merging it!

Thanks!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: remove the text-based linters for module docstring, copyright and author lines

I suggest an experiment: add a file that breaks the rules and see that the new linter actually catches the errors. But probably people who are more involved in CI and metaprogramming have better ideas.
I just added such a file, the linter works locally. Does that look sufficient to you? (If CI fails, I'll remove it again.)

The test here also seems to work: besides the fact that the "new" definition does not have a doc-string, there are also `build` errors coming from the malformed copyright header.

My main reason for not being immediately enthusiastic about removing these "text-based" linters is that the syntax linter will typically lint `Mathlib.Init` and whatever imports that, but the text-based ones also cover the "early" files.

Wasn't the point of `Mathlib.Init` that every file imports it (or is imported in it)?
Checking the copyright headers of all these syntax linters is nice, I agree - but I don't think keeping a separate linter implementation around just for them is an appropriate cost-benefit ratio.

For these particular linters, that should not be too hard to enforce by hand, though... in practice, these seem to be violated out of ignorance more than anything else.

Looks good to me!

I see that Bryan self-assigned this PR, so I won't maintainer merge, in case he wants to add something, but I am happy with merging it!

Thanks!

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: import the `header` linter in all files imported in Mathlib.Init

nodes.body: @adomani I just wrote #18725, importing the `header` linter in every file that is imported in Mathlib.Init. This should ensure all files are checked for missing copyright (or module doc-string). Does that assugae your concerns on this PR?

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(scripts): require all scripts to be documented in the README
